data.title: Roberta Taylor, EastEnders Actress, Dies at 76
data.meta_description: Roberta Taylor, renowned for her role as Irene Raymond in 'EastEnders' and Inspector Gina Gold in 'The Bill', has passed away at the age of 76 due to an infection stemming from a fall two months prior. Her underlying health issues, including pneumonia and emphysema, contributed to her decline. Taylor's career spanned various stages, including performances in the West End and with the Royal Shakespeare Company, with her last TV appearance in 'Shakespeare & Hathaway'. Born in Plaistow, east London, she is survived by her husband Peter Guinness, son Elliott, a granddaughter, and two stepbrothers. Tributes have poured in for the beloved actress who captivated audiences with her tough yet tender portrayals on screen.
data.text:
Roberta Taylor's acting career spanned several decades and included significant roles in both television and stage productions. She first garnered widespread recognition for her role as Irene Raymond in 'EastEnders,' a popular BBC soap opera, from 1997 to 2000. This role, where she played the matriarch of the Hills family, brought her mainstream attention. She then transitioned to the role of Inspector Gina Gold on ITV's 'The Bill,' which solidified her reputation as a versatile actress capable of strong dramatic performances. Besides television, she also acted on stage, including performances with the Royal Shakespeare Company and in the West End, highlighting her diverse acting abilities. Her last notable television role was in 'Shakespeare & Hathaway,' demonstrating her continued relevance in the British entertainment industry.

Roberta Taylor's early life was marked by modest beginnings and personal challenges. Born in Plaistow, east London, to a family of bus conductors, she grew up in a small house on the Isle of Dogs with her mother, grandmother, and aunts after her father left the family. These formative experiences of resilience and close familial bonds likely influenced her ability to portray complex characters with depth and authenticity. Her background may have informed her choice of roles that often depicted strong, resilient women, such as the tough mother Irene Raymond in 'EastEnders' and the hard-drinking Inspector Gina Gold in 'The Bill.' Her work with the Royal Shakespeare Company and in the West End also suggests a commitment to pursuing diverse and challenging roles throughout her career.

Roberta Taylor struggled with emphysema, a chronic lung condition that can significantly impair respiratory function. This underlying health issue made her particularly vulnerable to complications from pneumonia, which she developed after a fall two months prior to her passing. The infection from the fall exacerbated her already compromised respiratory system, leading to a prolonged infection that she could not overcome. The combination of emphysema and pneumonia ultimately contributed to her death at the age of 76.
